advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-60</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from a Commodore brochure.<br> Notice that the girl seems not to be interested at all in the computer...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 816/C VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 816/C version was a multi-user system featuring:<br> - Dual CPU (8085 + 8088) motherboard<br> - 384 KB of RAM, expandable to 1 MB<br> - 2 x 1.2 MB 8" F.D. drives<br> - 9 serial ports<br> - 3 to 16 users expansion<br><br> As the magazine 'computer Age' said, this system was almost twice as quick as an IBM-PC. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #11</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRAPPING MAN!</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> A compact problem-solving add for engineers, statisticians, scientists and financial and business analysts. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advertisement for the HX-10D. If you can read japanese maybe you could tell us what's the difference with a HX-10...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Stop in a store near you. Take a look. You'll be instantly taken with some of the features that make the IBM Personal Computer so different...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Strange logo isn't it?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - NOV.1981</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Texas Instruments TMS 9918/A or TMS 9928/A (Japan : 60 Hz) or TMS 9929/A (Europe : 50 Hz)
computer.description:
Very basic MSX "1" computer. It is the entry-level system of the Sony MSX range. It has got all the minimum features specified by the MSX 1 specifications: 64 KB RAM, two cartridge slots, 70 keys, etc.
It has no built-in software applications unlike its brother, the HB-11.
It was sold with different colored cases. Red in Japan (only), and black for exportations systems. Like most Sony HB (Hit-Bit) systems, exported systems have a letter at the end of their names indicating the targeted country: D for Germany (Deutchland), F for France, etc...
Juan Jose Velez adds: These MSX HB-11 computers were sold in Mexico with a Spanish keyboard (also with translated on-computer-printed-info, like the "turn off the computer before inserting or removing a cart" you found near the cart ports) in just one group of stores citywide: a women's clothes boutique called "Superbella".

emulator.description: A Bresilian MSX Emulator written in 100% assembler

emulator.description: A MSX Emulator for Win95 and Win NT + Direct X
emulator.name: RuMSX

emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.
emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.

computer.graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites

Panasonic FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br> It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br> Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 70 keys (including 5 F-keys and 4 arrow keys)
computer.name: Hit-Bit 10
computer.ports: Joystick socket (1 or 2), Cardridge slot (1 or 2), Tape-recorder plug (1200/2400 bauds), RGB video output, Centronics interface
